My banks are all furnished with rags,</br>So thick — even Fred cannot thin 'em;</br>I've torn up my old money-bags,</br>Having nothing, worth while, to put in 'em.</br>My tradesmen are smashing by dozens,</br>But this is all nothing, they say;</br>For bankrupts, since Adam, are cousins,</br>So, it's all in the family way.

My Debt not a penny takes from me,</br>As sages the matter explain;—</br>Bob owes it to Tom, and then Tommy</br>Just owes it to Bob back again.</br>Since all have thus taken to owing,</br>There's nobody left that can pay;</br>And this is the way to keep going,</br>All quite in the family way.

My senators vote away millions,</br>To put in Prosperity's budget;</br>And though it were billions or trillions,</br>The generous rogues wouldn't grudge it.</br>'Tis all but a family hop,</br>'Twas Pitt began dancing the hay;</br>Hands round! — why the deuce should we stop?</br>'Tis all in the family way.

My labourers used to eat mutton,</br>As any great man of the State does;</br>And now the poor devils are put on</br>Small rations of tea and potatoes.</br>But cheer up, John, Sawney, and Paddy,</br>The King is your father, they say;</br>So, ev'n if you starve for your Daddy,</br>'Tis all in the family way.

My rich manufacturers tumble,</br>My poor ones have little to chew;</br>And, ev'n if themselves do not grumble,</br>Their stomachs undoubtedly do.</br>But coolly to fast, en famille,</br>Is as good for the soul as to pray;</br>And famine itself is genteel,</br>When one starves in a family way.

I have found out a secret for Freddy,</br>A secret for next budget day;</br>Though, perhaps, he may know it already,</br>As he, too, 's a sage in his way.</br>When next for the Treasury scene he</br>Announces "the Devil to pay,"</br>Let him write on the bills, "Nota bene,</br>'Tis all in the family way."</br>
